results.title: Dean and Donna
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Sandra Richardson, Martyn Down, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Part of a series designed to facilitate discussion of various issues and themes related to social education, human relations and personal development and designed for use with primary-school and lower secondary school children in the 8 to 14 year age range. This part looks at Donna and Dean who are learning to adjust to different ‘blended family’ situations. Donna and her natural brother Scott have joined older brothers and sisters. Donna is now no longer the eldest. Dean lives with his father and new step-mother. They have recently had a baby. Explores the feelings they express while they are seeking to make the necessary readjustments.

results.title: Tracey and Trevor
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Sandra Richardson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”
Tracey and Trevor discuss how they feel about being a girl and a boy. They reveal their own values and comment on the expectations and prejudices of others, including their friends family and society. The film looks at conflicts faced by children who do not wish to conform to commonly-held sex-role stereotypes.

results.title: Stephanie
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Sandra Richardson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
The film gives insights into Stephanie’s strategy for coping with a physical handicap. Her attitude towards others with intellectual and physical handicaps is revealed in her interactions with her sister at home and with handicapped children who visit her school.

results.title: Shane
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Sandra Richardson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Shane identifies himself as ‘dumb’. The film examines some of the perceptions his parents, siblings and peers hold about Shane by showing him at his school and at his home. The interactions in these two settings illustrate some causes and consequences of low self-esteem

results.title: Sean and Joel
results.creator_credit: Ian Monroe, Sandra Richardson, Ian Munro, Martyn Down, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Sean and Joel realise that their father has left home for good. He has remarried and the boys have stayed with their single mother. Their feelings about their new situation are revealed as they learn to adjust to the aftermath of parental separation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Monroe, Sandra Richardson, Ian Munro, Martyn Down, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: The Gang
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Sandra Richardson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Honadie, Julie and Joanne are members of a gang. They believe that their peers are submissive to them because of the violence the gang has used and has threatened to use. Emphasis is on the co-operative efforts of the school, the parents and the girls themselves to effect changes in their behaviour.

results.title: Honie
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Sandra Richardson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Honie has an Aboriginal mother and an English father and lives in an inner suburb of a large Australian city. The film provides insights into her view of her own identity. An examination of her experiences within school, home and community leads to an awareness of aspects of Aboriginal culture important to Honie and her family.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Munro, Sandra Richardson, Tom Manefield and Film Australia

results.title: The Career escalator
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey, Australia Japan Foundation and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
We meet Yuichi, a ‘ronin’ student studying for his final entrance exams to a top university, and Oka, a senior executive at Mitsubishi. The intense competition and unique processes of commercial life and the structure of the Japanese education system from kindergarten to tertiary level are featured in this film. Narrated by Peter Gwynne. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: A Working couple
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Most Japanese live in the big cities, many of them are salaried company workers, living in housing estates and traveling long distances to work. For many people, life is a struggle. This focuses of Mr Yokohama, a professional office employee and his wife who runs a chemist. Their lives provide an insight as to what its like to live in Tokyo, with a population of twelve million.
